turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: You still shouldn't have done it, Charlie.  You don't speak for the club.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Hey, would you not worry about your precious little necks?  If they catch me, I'll tell them I made it up.  All your asses are safe.  Look, Gloria and Tina didn't come here to listen to us argue. Are we gonna have a meeting or what?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What happened? Were you kicked out?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'm supposed to turn everybody in, apologize to the school and all will be forgiven.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What are you going to do? - Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Damn it, Neil, the name is Nuwanda.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Why don't you talk to Mr. Keating about it?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What good will that do?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Maybe he'll have some advice.  Maybe he'll even talk to your father.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Are you kidding?  Don't be ridiculous.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: This is stupid.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It's better than doing nothing.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: It's all right, Chet.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: It's not all right.  Come on, Dad

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Chris.  We got it.  Let's go.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Nice meeting you, Knox.  Bye, Gin.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Oh Chet, that feels fabulous,

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: It does?  What?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You know,

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Don't stop.

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: Stop what?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Chet...

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: What are you doing?!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox?!

turns.speaker: CHET
turns.text: You fucked up little prick!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Chet, you don't have to hurt him.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Pleased to meet you.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: The pleasure is mine.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: So, uh, where are you in school?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Ridgeway High.  How's Henley Hall, Gin?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: That's your sister school, right?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Sort of.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You going out for the Henley Hall play?  They're doing "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Hello Chris, this is Knox Overstress.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox.  Oh yes, Knox.  I'm glad you called.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: You are?  She's glad I called!

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Well, sure!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Chet's parents don't know about it, so please keep it quiet.  But you can bring someone if you like.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I'll be there.  The Danburrys.  Friday night.  Thank you, Chris.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Oh, hi.  I'm glad you made it.  Did you bring anybody?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Ginny Danburry's here.  Look for her.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: But, Chris...

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I gotta find Chet.  Make yourself at home.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: carpe breastum.  Seize the breast.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Chris!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox!  what are you doing here?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: If Chet sees you, he'll kill you, don't you know that?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I don't care.  I love you, Chris.  You deserve better than Chet and I'm it. Please accept these.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox, you're crazy.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox, I don't believe this!

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: All I'm asking you to do is listen.  "The heavens made a girl named Chris, With hair and skin of gold To touch her would be paradise To kiss her glory untold."

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Chris!

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox, why are you doing this to me?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: You can't be in here.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: If they catch you here, we'll both be in big trouble.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Oh, but it's fine for you to come barging into my school and make a complete fool out of me?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I didn't mean to make a fool of you.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Well, you did!  Chet found out and he's nuts.  It took everything I could do to keep him from coming here and killing you. You have to stop this stuff, Knox.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: But I love you.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: You say that over and over but you don't even know me!

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Of course I know you!  From the first time I saw you, I knew you had a wonderful soul.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Just like that?!  You just knew?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Of course just like that.  That's how you always know when it's right.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: And if it so happens that you're wrong? If it just so happens that I could care less About you?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Then you wouldn't be here warning me about Chet.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Look, I've got to go.  I'm gonna be late for the play.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Are you going with Chet?

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Chet?  To a play? Are you kidding?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Then come with me.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox, you are so infuriating!

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Just give me one chance.  If you don't like me after tonight, I'll stay away forever.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I promise.  Dead Poets honor.  Come with me tonight, then if you don't want to see me again, I swear I'll bow out.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: God, if Chet found out he'd...

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Chet won't know anything.  We'll sit in back and sneak away as soon as it's over.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: Knox, if you promise that this will be the end of it-

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Dead Poets honor.

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: What is that?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: My Word

turns.speaker: CHRIS
turns.text: I have to go home. Chet might call.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: It's just for a little while. You promised.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: We thought it would be good to break old habits, sir.

turns.speaker: HAGER
turns.text: What is wrong with old habits, Mr. Overstreet?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: They perpetuate mechanical living, sir. They limit your mind.

turns.speaker: HAGER
turns.text: Mr. Overstreet, I suggest you worry less about breaking old habits and more about developing good study habits.  Do you understand?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: HAGER
turns.text: That goes for all of you.  Now eat with your correct hands.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Gather ye rosebuds while ye may.  The Latin term for that sentiment is "Carpe Diem." Anyone know what that means?

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: Carpe Diem... seize the day.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Very good, Mr._?

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: Meeks.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Seize the day while you're young, see that you make use of your time.  Why does the poet write these lines?

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: The hoi polloi.  Doesn't it mean the herd?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Precisely, Meeks. Greek for the herd. However, be warned that, when you say "the hoi polloi" you are actually saying the the herd.  Indicating that you too are "hoi polloi."

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: And don't limit poetry to the word. Poetry can be found in a work of art, music, a photograph, in the way a meal is prepared--anything with the stuff of revelation in it.  It can exist in the most everyday things but it must never, never be ordinary  By all means, write about the sky or a girl's smile but when you do, let your poetry conjure up salvation day, doomsday, any day, I don't care, as long as it enlightens us, thrills us and--if it's inspired--makes us feel a bit immortal.

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: Oh, Captain, My Captain. Is there poetry in math?

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: Oh Captain, My Captain.  What if we don't know anything about someone like Rahesh Non?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Rahesh Non never existed, Mr. Meeks. You make him or someone like him up.  No self important college professor such as this one would dare admit ignorance of such an obviously important figure and you will probably receive a comment similar to the one I received:

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: We used to meet here on special occasions. Who would like to convene the meeting?

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: "We went to the woods because we wanted to suck all the marrow out of life." Anybody want to read?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: This was my first classroom, John, did you know that?  My first desk.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: I didn't know you taught.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: English.  Way before your time.  It was hard giving it up, I'll tell you.  I'm hearing rumors, John, of some unusual teaching methods in your classroom.  I'm not saying they have anything to do with the Dalton boy's outburst, but I don't think I have to warn you that boys his age are very impressionable.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Your reprimand made quite an impression I'm sure.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: What was going on in the courtyard the other day?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Courtyard?

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: Boys marching.  Clapping in unison.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Oh that. That was an exercise to prove a point.  About the evils of conformity.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: John, the curriculum here is set.  It's proven.  It works.  If you question it, what's to prevent them from doing the same?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: I always thought education was learning to think for yourself.

turns.speaker: NOLAN
turns.text: At these boys' age? Not on your life! Tradition, John.  Discipline.  Prepare them for college, and the rest will take care of itself.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: A yawp?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: A barbaric yawp.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Good god, boy! Yell!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Yawp!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Again!  Louder!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: YAWP!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: LOUDER!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: AHHHHHH!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: All right!  Very good!  There's a barbarian in there after all!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Todd, there's a picture of Whitman over the door.  What does he remind you Of? Quickly, Anderson, don't think about it.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: A madman.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: A madman.  Perhaps he was.  What kind of madman?  Don't think!  Answer.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: A crazy madman.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Use your imagination!  First thing that pops to your mind, even if it's gibberish!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: A... A  sweaty-toothed madman.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Now there's the poet speaking!  Close your eyes and think of the picture. Describe what you see.  NOW!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I... I close my eyes.  His image floats beside me.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: A sweaty-toothed madman

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: A sweaty-toothed madman with a stare that pounds my brain.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Excellent!  Have him act.  Give it rhythm!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: His hands reach out and choke me All the time he mumbles slowly.  Truth... Truth is like a blanket that always leaves your feet cold.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Stretch it, pull it, it will never cover any of us.  Kick at it, beat at it, it will never be enough-

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Don't stop!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: From the moment we enter crying to the moment we leave dying,  It will cover just your head as you wail and cry and scream!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Come on boys, don't be shy.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I have something.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Mr. Keating? Sir? Oh Captain My Captain.  What was the Dead Poets Society?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Ah, so you boy's have been snooping.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I was just looking in an old annual and...

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Nothing wrong with research.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What did the name mean.  Did you only read dead poets.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: All poetry was acceptable.  The name simply referred to the fact, that to join the organization, you had to be dead.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Oh Captain, My Captain, we came here so I could talk to you about something.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Actually, I'd like to talk to you alone.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Gosh, they don't give you much room around here, do they?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Maybe they don't want worldly things distracting me from my teaching.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Why do you do it?  I mean, with all this seize-the-day business, I'd have thought you'd be out seeing the world or something?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Ah, but I am seeing the world, Neil. The new world.  Seeing a student like you take root and bloom.  It's worth everything.  That's why I came back here. A place like this needs at least one teacher like me.  Did you come here to talk about my teaching?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Mr. Keating, my father is making me quit the play at Henley Hall.  When I think about carpe diem and all that, I feel like I'm in prison!  I mean, I can see his point.  We're not a rich family like Charlie's.  But he's planned the rest of my life for me and he's never even asked me what I want!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: You can't live a life for someone else, Neil.  You can only live for yourself. Have you told your father what you just told me?  Have you shown him your passion about acting?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Are you kidding?  He'd kill me!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Then you're playing a part for him too, aren't you?  A dangerously self- destructive one.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Neil, I know this seems impossible but you have to go to your father and show him what you're feeling.  You have to let him see who you are-  It's your only chance.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I know what he'll say.  He'll say that acting is just a whim and that it's frivolous and that I should forget about it.  He'll tell me how they're counting on me and to put it out of my mind "for my own good."

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Well, if it's more than a whim, then you'll have to prove that to him.  You'll have to show him with your passion and commitment that it's what you really want to do.  If that doesn't work, at least by then you'll be eighteen and able to do what you want.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Eighteen!  That's two years!  What about the play?  The performance is tomorrow night!

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Give your father the benefit of the doubt.  Talk to him.  Let him see who you are.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Isn't there an easier way?

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Not if you're going to stay true to yourself.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: What did your father say? Did you talk to him?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KEATING
turns.text: Really?  You told your father what you told me?  You let him see your passion for acting?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yeah.  He didn't like it one bit but at least he's letting me stay in the play. Of course, he won't be able to come. He'll be in Chicago on business.  But I think he's gonna let me stay with acting.  As long as I keep my grades up.

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: Too bad.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: It's not too bad.  It's a tragedy! Why does she have to be in love with a jerk?!

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: All the good ones go for jerks, you know that.  Forget her.  Take out your trig book and figure out problem twelve.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I can't just forget her, Pitts.  And I certainly can't think about math!

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: You really think I should forget her?

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: You have another choice.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Damn.  Damn!  If I could just get Chris to read this poem!

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: Why don't you read it to her? It worked for Nuwanda.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: She won't even see me, Pitts.

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: Nuwanda recited poetry to Gloria and she jumped all over him... right, Nuwanda?

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: All right!  What'd she say?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: Wait a minute.  I don't let my parents walk on me.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yeah, you just do everything they say! You'll be in daddy's law firm as sure as I'm standing here.  And you'll be approving loans till you croak.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: All right.  Jesus, what are you gonna do?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What I have to do.  Screw the annual.

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: They're friends of my dad.  Probably in their nineties or something.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Listen, anything's, better than mystery meat.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Are you crazy? What's wrong with that?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: She's practically engaged to Chet Danburry.  Mr. Mondo Jocko himself.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: You know what the dead poets would say: Gather ye rosebuds while ye may...

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: But she's in love with: the moron son of my father's best friend.  What would the dead poets say about that?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Where are you going?

turns.speaker: KNOX
turns.text: I'm calling her!

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: I certainly wouldn't lose any sleep over it.  It's just a bunch of people trying to impress Nolan.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Screw it all.  I don't give a damn about any of it.

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: Any group pictures in the annual?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Nothing.  No mention of it.

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: His grades are hurting, Charlie.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Then you can help him.

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: If you have built castles in the air, your work need not be lost.  That is where they should be.  Now put foundations under them.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: God, I want to do everything!  I'm going to explode.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I gotta get to the tryouts.  Wish me luck.

turns.speaker: MEEKS
turns.text: Good luck.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: But father, I'm assistant editor.

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: I'm sorry, Neil.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: But father, it's not fair.

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: Fellows, would you excuse us a minute?

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: I will not be disputed in public, do you understand me?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Father, I wasn't disputing you.

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: When you've finished medical school and you're on your own, you can do as you please.  Until then, you will listen to me.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yes sir.  I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: You know what this means to your mother, don't you?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: You know me, always taking on too much.

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: Good boy.  Call us if you need anything.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Father!

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: Neil, you are going to quit this ridiculous play immediately.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Father, I--

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: Don't you dare talk back to me!  It's bad enough that you've wasted your time with this absurd acting business.  But you deliberately deceived me!  Who put this in your head? How did you expect to get away with it? Answer me!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Nobody-  I thought I'd surprise you. I've got all As and-

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: Did you really think I wouldn't find out?!  "My niece is in a play with your son," Mrs. Marks says.  "You must be mistaken," I say.  "My son isn't in a play."  You made a liar out of me, Neil! Now you will go tomorrow and tell them you are quitting.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Father, I have the main part.  The performance is tomorrow night.  Father, please.

turns.speaker: MR. PERRY
turns.text: I don't care if the world is coming to an end tomorrow night, you are through with that play!  Is that clear?  Is that clear!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: Weird.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: But different.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I say we go tonight.  Everybody in?

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: Where is this cave he's talking about?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Beyond the stream.  I think I know.

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: That's miles.

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: What is this, a midnight study group?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Forget it, Pitts, you're coming.  Meeks, your grades hurting too?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Look at this.

turns.speaker: PITTS
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: The god of the cave.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I hear we're going to be roommates. Neil Perry.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Todd Anderson.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Why'd you leave Balincrest?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: My brother went here.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Oh, so you're that Anderson.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: My parents wanted me here all along but my grades weren't good enough.  I had to go to Balincrest to pull them up.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Well, you've won the booby prize.  Don't expect to like it here.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I don't.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: So what do you think of my father?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I'll take him over mine.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Todd, if you're gonna make it around here, you've gotta speak up.  The meek might inherit the earth but they don't get into Harvard. know what I mean?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Want to come to the study group?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Thanks but  I'd better do history.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What is it then?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I... I just don't want to come.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: But why?  Don't you understand what Keating is saying?  Don't you want to do something about it?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Yes.  But

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Put what?  Goddamn it, tell me.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I don't want to read.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Keating said everybody took turns reading.  I don't want to do it.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: God, you really have a problem, don't you?  How can it hurt you to read?  I mean isn't that what this is all about? Expressing yourself?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I've found it.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Found what?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: What I want to do!  Right now. What is really inside of me.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: A Midsummer Night's Dream. What is it?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: A play, dummy.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I know that.  What's it got to do with you?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: They're putting it on at Henley Hall. See, open try-outs.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: So I'm gonna act!  Ever since I can remember I've wanted to try it.  Last summer I even tried to go to summer stock auditions but of course my father wouldn't let me.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: And now he will?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Hell no, but that's not the point.  The point is for the first time in my whole goddamned life, I know what I want, and for the first time I'm gonna do it whether my father wants me to or not! Carpe diem, goddamn it!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Neil, how are you gonna be in a play if your father won't let you?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: First I gotta get the part, then I'll worry about that.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Won't he kill you if you don't let him know you're auditioning?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: As far as I'm concerned, he won't have to know about any of it.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Come on, that's impossible.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Horseshit.  Nothing's impossible.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Why don't you ask him first?  Maybe he'll say yes.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: That's a laugh.  If I don't ask, at least I won't be disobeying him.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: But if he said no before then...

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Jesus Christ, whose side are you on?  I haven't even gotten the part yet.  Can't I enjoy the idea even for a little while?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: By the way, there's a meeting this afternoon.  You coming?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I guess.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: None of what Mr. Keating has to say means shit to you, does it?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: What is that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Being in the club means being stirred up by things.  You look about as stirred up as a cesspool.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: You want me out...  is that what you're saying?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: No, I want you in.  But being in means you gotta do something.  Not just say you're in.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Listen Neil, I appreciate your interest in me but I'm not like you.  When you say things, people pay attention.  People follow you.  I'm not like that.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Why not?  Don't you think you could be?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: No!  I don't know,  I'll probably never know.  The point is, there's nothing you can do about it so butt out, all right? I can take care of myself just fine.  All right?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Er  No.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: No?  What do you mean 'no'?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Neil, how are you gonna do this?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Sssh.  That's what I'm taking care of. They need a letter of permission.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: From you?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: From my father and Nolan.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Neil, you're not gonna...

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Quiet.  I have to think.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Todd, what's the matter?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: It's my birthday.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: It is?  Happy Birthday.  You get anything?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: This is your desk set.  I don't get it.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: They gave me the exact same thing as last year!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Oh..

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Well, maybe they thought you'd need another one.  Maybe they thought...

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Maybe they don't think at all unless it's about my brother!  His birthday's always a big to-do.  The stupid thing is, I didn't even like the first one.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Look, Todd, you're obviously under- estimating the value of this desk set.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: what?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I mean, this is one special gift!  Who would want a football or a baseball bat or a car when they could get a desk set as wonderful as this one!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Yeah!  And just look at this ruler!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Here, villain, draw and ready. where art thou?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I will be with thee straight.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Follow me then to plainer ground.  God, I love this!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: This play?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Yes, and acting!  It's got to be one of the most wonderful things in the world. Most people, if they're lucky, live about half an exciting life! If I could get the parts, I could live dozens of lives.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: You should come to rehearsals.  I know they need people to work the lights and stuff.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: No thanks.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Lots of girls.  The girl who plays Hermia is incredible.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: I'll come to the performance.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Chicken shit.  Where were we?

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Yea, art thou there?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Put more into it!

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: YEA, ART THOU THERE?!

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: That's it!  "Follow my voice.  We'll try no manhood here."  See you at dinner.

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: Visit from my father.

turns.speaker: TODD
turns.text: Do you have to quit the play?

turns.speaker: NEIL
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: You the Captain?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: How do we get out of here?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: We have to make it to the third deck...

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: He's the owner...

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Why don't you want a message sent?

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: It's not going to help us!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: We're going to die here! We're going to die!

turns.speaker: CAPTAIN
turns.text: They are...they are everywhere.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: All right, be cool, everybody, nice and slow, no sudden moves.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MAMOOLI
turns.text: Someone...maybe they sent an SOS!

turns.speaker: MAMOOLI
turns.text: We don't even know if his boat is still there...you saw Billy!

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Boat or no boat...I'm going...

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Nobody's shooting nobody...come on, just let us through the hatch!

turns.speaker: MAMOOLI
turns.text: I'll kill you!! I'll fucking kill you!! I'll do it! I'll do it! I'm not playin' around here!

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: I once saw a guy put a fish in a bottle, then he corked it, sealing it tight, and threw it to a baby octopus. The little sucker felt its way around that bottle, and in less than two minutes, got that cork off, slid inside, and ate that fish.

turns.speaker: MAMOOLI
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about?

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Us...I'm talking about us... We're the fish.

turns.speaker: MAMOOLI
turns.text: And what? These things are octopusses?

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: I don't know what these things are ...all I know is...

turns.speaker: HANOVER
turns.text: You remember the first time we met Finnegan? I think you were just starting out...smuggling gold off Sumatra for those two Chinese...what did we use to call them?

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Fok Yu and Fok Yu Two...are we strolling down memory lane for any particular reason?

turns.speaker: HANOVER
turns.text: No, it just struck me as odd...I don't see you for all these years and you've still got the same tape stuck in the box.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: You know what they say...the classics are eternal.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Right here...middle of nowhere...

turns.speaker: HANOVER
turns.text: And where is our point of arrival?

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: Right here...middle of nowhere...and the answer to your question is yes.

turns.speaker: HANOVER
turns.text: Which question is that?

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: The one you came up to ask...are we on schedule?

turns.speaker: HANOVER
turns.text: Take note Mr. Mason...this is why you hire a professional...No whining. No excuses.

turns.speaker: HANOVER
turns.text: Don't mind him Finnegan...you remember 25...balls of steel... splashing around in a sea of testosterone.

turns.speaker: FINNEGAN
turns.text: I don't mind him...but I do think it's time for him to get back down below with the rest of the playgroup.
